@inconvergent fwiw, I write most of my code in vim, but import/reload functions into my notebook. So I use it more as a graphical terminal.
@inconvergent Tried to find a particular example on github, but I'm on my phone and GH doesn't seem render notebooks on mobile.
@inconvergent but it's more about the story of how someone got to a solution, that can include failures. By context I meant the human ctxt.
@inconvergent I think if you had an editor which showed images or graphs from raw data that'd help. I hear xcode can do markdown images...
@inconvergent yeah, I'm not unfamiliar with comments... but it's clear we have different use cases.
@inconvergent For kaggle competition entries I much prefer to read a notebook than context-less code or non specific blog posts.
@inconvergent @DanCouper I love vim, but when I'm doing research, exploring an imgproc API, prototyping a CV alg: visual feedback is great.
@inconvergent @DanCouper it's actually great for research where you have to explore and visualise data. It's a record of work.
@inconvergent a row of bots.

@WLTaskForce Congratulations you have turned into the security apparatus you once fought against.
@stevesi thanks!
@stevesi are there examples of malicious agents attacking the supply chain? Sounds like you've investigated tho, any book you recc?
@stevesi harder to attribute liability when it's a heterogeneous group of a million insecure IoT devices.
@stevesi cars risk death, businesses have liability there, nobody cares about the IoT botnets responsible for ddos.
@stevesi admittedly that was a couple of years ago, maybe it's impossible to get a dumb TV now.
@stevesi last time I tried to buy a TV there were only SmartTVs at my price point. $2k more and I could get a kick ass TV without gimmicks.
@stevesi meanwhile, consumers will pay a premium for the disconnected secure version. Not data monitoring so includea the "privacy" feature
@stevesi all other computer security problems become trivial.
@stevesi I look forward to them solving the computer security problem, because if they can solve it for discontinued IoT products...
@rickasaurus what would you have to sacrifice? (apart from a little bit of speed)
